messages.title: Revealed: Conservative plan to slash services
messages.content: The Conservatives have demanded £57 million in cuts for local services and have only identified savings of around £1 million, resulting in potential service reductions.

messages.title: More for less
messages.content: Lib Dems provide an extra £72 million for road repairs following the winter damage. The Lib Dems have also found £2 million in money-saving ideas over the last year.

messages.title: Labour votes could let the Tories back.
messages.content: Labour votes could indirectly help the Conservative party.

messages.title: Public spending is cut in the usual way – slash and burn
messages.content: Negative comments on Conservative spending cuts.

keyPolicies.policyDescription: Lib Dems invested an additional £72 million for road repairs and identified £2 million in savings.
Investments in schools at Kingsway and Cheadle Royal Junction, and School Hill Road / Wilmslow Road junction. Also, addressing school crossing locations problem.
Despite difficult financial times, Lib Dems have protected services without the need for the Conservatives' planned severe cuts.

mentions.tacticalSituation: Labour votes could let the Tories back.

issues.economy: Lib Dems have found £2 million in money-saving ideas over the last year, improving the economy of the constituency.
issues.governance: Conservatives plan severe cuts, while Lib Dems protect services and manage budget more efficiently.

housing.content: Road repairs and investments in education.

politicalExperience.achievements: Secured £2 million investment for local schools, worked on road repairs and saving money in the constituency.

quotes.text: "If public spending is cut in the usual way – slash and burn – there will be great damage to local and national services. Good will be cut with bad. Frontline services will be butchered and lower paid workers will bear the brunt of cuts."
quotes.source: Vince Cable, Liberal Democrat Shadow Chancellor

images.caption: Labour votes could let the Tories back.
Lib Dems deliver on Cheadle & Gatley's roads.
